author: schone_wizard
content: Given the current inability to reach finality. If this were to happen on mainnet. Does the current slashing situation incentivizes stakers to keep their validators offline? Thinking that the penalty for being offline is slower to dwindle their balances compared to attesting and finding that after finality happens you voted for the wrong fork and got slashed

author: djrtwo
content: "voting for the wrong fork" does not get you slashed

author: djrtwo
content: each epoch, you can revise your vote depending on the head chain you see

author: djrtwo
content: you just can't vote twice in an epoch or vote in a way that "forgets" your previous vote (a surround vote in FFG)

author: schone_wizard
content: The surround vote was what I was imagining to be the killer

author: schone_wizard
content: But I probably have my understanding wrong

author: djrtwo
content: your source is the latest justified you see. if you follow the protocol, justifications will strictly increase

author: djrtwo
content:
There is no risk of attester slashing if you strictly follow the protocol
* only vote on epochs greater than your previous vote
* only increase latest justifications

author: eth2_bridge_bot
content:

author: eth2_bridge_bot

author: schone_wizard
content: Can you explain please how the changing of clients could result in slashing risk

author: djrtwo
content: If for example, client-A was 1000 epochs in the future and you changed to client-B without remembering your latest attestation

author: schone_wizard
content: Would waiting a full epoch between changing clients mitigate that problem?

author: djrtwo
content: then you would start double voting

author: djrtwo
content: If neither client ever went into the future (clock skew) and they followed the two rules I wrote above, then waiting 1+ epoch would be safe

author: djrtwo
content: so for the purposes of swapping on this current testnet, that's probably okay

author: djrtwo
content: but since the incident on friday, clients have been working on a VC interchange format to be extra safe

author: djrtwo
content: interchange format: https://hackmd.io/@sproul/Bk0Y0qdGD

author: djrtwo
content: WIP lighthouse PR to implement the format: https://github.com/sigp/lighthouse/pull/1544

content: Thank you for that explanation. I’ll go take a look at the interchange format

author: djrtwo
content: again, the main thing that would get you if you just did the "wait N epochs" would be if the clients had a client skew of greater than N epochs

>  Eventually you’d have a double vote into the future
yes, exactly.

if you at least export your latest vote to the new VC, then you can be 100% protected following a couple of simple rules around that vote
if you export your entire slashing prtection DB to new VC, then you can be 100% protected and a little bit more flexible in your vote crafting (e.g. in your example you could vote for 2401 to 2699, and then skip 2700)
